required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopic Imaging Study of Prostatic Fats to Distinguish the Difference Between High and Low Risk Prostate Cancer
clinical_study.official_title: Imaging Prostatic Lipids to Distinguish Aggressive Prostate Cancer

brief_summary.textblock: A prostate cancer diagnosis starts a list of events that often leads to fast-moving treatment, thought by many to result in vast over-treatment of this disease. So, discovery of different diagnostic methods that allow clinicians to identify slow-growing from potentially fast-growing disease prior to or at the time of prostate biopsy could result in early and suitable treatment for men at greatest risk, while greatly decreasing the number of biopsies, surgical procedures, hormonal and chemotherapeutic treatments, cost, and patient worry, for those with more slow-growing disease.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of participants with increased intraprostatic lipid concentration
primary_outcome.description: Determine the correlation between the amount of intraprostatic lipid using 1H (proton) magnetic resonance spectroscopic imaging (MRSI) with an endorectal coil obtained prior to prostatectomy with fatty acid synthase protein expression measured in benign and cancer tissue from prostatectomy samples.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of participants with increased tumor aggressiveness
secondary_outcome.description: Identify the association between fatty acid synthase protein expression in prostatectomy samples, intraprostatic lipid as measured by 1H MRSI, and prostate tumor aggressiveness.

other_outcome.measure: Number of participants with accumulation of lipid intermediates and proteins
other_outcome.description: To quantify the association between key metabolic intermediates involved in lipid metabolism, mitochondrial function, inflammation, and apoptosis in prostatectomy samples and fatty acid synthase protein expression, intraprostatic lipid and tumor aggressiveness.

arm_group.description: Men who have been recently diagnosed with high risk prostate cancer (Gleason score 7 and above) and who choose prostate removal for their cancer treatment will undergo Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy Imaging (MRSI) with rectal probe at the Oregon Health & Science University's Advanced Imaging Research Center.

Men who have been recently diagnosed with low risk prostate cancer (Gleason score 7 [3+4] and below) and who choose prostate removal for their cancer treatment will undergo Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy Imaging (MRSI) with rectal probe at the Oregon Health & Science University's Advanced Imaging Research Center.

intervention.intervention_name: Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy Imaging with rectal probe

biospec_descr.textblock: Blood, Urine, Prostatic fluid and Prostatectomy tissue

study_pop.textblock: all men newly-diagnosed with prostate cancer at the Portland VA and OHSU Urology clinics

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Prostate cancer diagnosis prior to treatment
- Age 21 years or older
- Signed informed subject consent
- Prostatectomy as planned prostate cancer treatment
Exclusion Criteria:
- Men who do not choose prostatectomy
- Men who have undergone any neoadjuvant therapy
- Men who have cardiac pacemakers or other implanted electronic devices
- Men who have any surgically implanted metal
- Men who have had any surgical procedure that precludes placement of endorectal probe
- Indication of dementia or memory issues listed on problem list
- Men who indicate exposure to ocular metal fragments; confirmed by positive ocular x-ray
- Men who are taking newly-prescribed (within 6 months of enrollment) lipid control medications

facility.name: Oregon Health & Science University Advanced Imaging Research Center
